text: As with any platform, it's only worth investing in if you know it's somewhere that your (ideal) customers hang out.

elements.text: As with any platform, it's only worth investing in if you know it's somewhere that your (ideal) customers hang out.

text: <@U017XD7H4P7>, thank you for the thoughtful and detailed response. I see what you're saying. I hear you loud and clear. And I agree that from this vantage point - sales does become the most important/ strategic aspect of any biz (solo, tiny or giant sized). However as an introvert, I find the self-promotional angle of sales to be most taxing (personally). At the same time I enjoy the deep/ strategic conversations I have with existing clients from time to time. So yes, I need to look inside myself and take a call on whether I want to go down the freelancer path with everything I've got. And leverage more of (2) than (1)... Or to go the other way... Especially if that's the way it's gonna be until I hit 7 figures (i'm a long way from that now). Thank you <@U017XD7H4P7>, once again for your time, patience and advice.

elements.text: , thank you for the thoughtful and detailed response. I see what you're saying. I hear you loud and clear. Especially if that's the way it's gonna be until I hit 7 figures (i'm a long way from that now). Thank you
, once again for your time, patience and advice.

text:
<@UUJBMDVGB> I realize that was a handful of questions rolled into one :wink: and thank you for offering to help.

_"I don't think doing all three necessarily lead to burnout"_ - I agree too. It's just sometimes that this feels stressful. Especially when you have a young family, are unable to dedicate 8+ hours of uninterrupted work and you need to attract more clients. But I guess to develop muscles you need to put them under some stress and lift some weights. Was only pondering if I was trying to lift too much, too quickly. For some context, even though I have 10+ years of experience as a consultant I stumbled into content marketing only a year ago. That's why account mgt of existing clients comes much more naturally to me. While I'm quickly developing content writing/ marketing muscles. Sales is something I know that is important as <@U017XD7H4P7> also mentioned. So it's definitely something I want to learn, practice and get better at.

_"you can definitely partner/pay other people to help with your lead gen and sales. But, you'll likely still need to play a big part in that sales process, and there's no escaping that you'll need to manage the work once they're signed up as a client"_ - I agree.

Like you put it _"Tl;dr it depends on your personal/professional goals"_ - Totally! I agree and that's what I'm taking out of this conversation. Thank you once again.

elements.text: I realize that was a handful of questions rolled into one

But I guess to develop muscles you need to put them under some stress and lift some weights. Was only pondering if I was trying to lift too much, too quickly. For some context, even though I have 10+ years of experience as a consultant I stumbled into content marketing only a year ago. That's why account mgt of existing clients comes much more naturally to me. While I'm quickly developing content writing/ marketing muscles. Sales is something I know that is important as
also mentioned. So it's definitely something I want to learn, practice and get better at.

"you can definitely partner/pay other people to help with your lead gen and sales. But, you'll likely still need to play a big part in that sales process, and there's no escaping that you'll need to manage the work once they're signed up as a client"

- I agree.

Like you put it
"Tl;dr it depends on your personal/professional goals"
- Totally! I agree and that's what I'm taking out of this conversation. Thank you once again.

text: Have you ever dabbled in brand as part of your content role? Do you have any resources to share on how to create a brand story, brand message, tone, etc? I'm looking to learn more about this and would love any recommendations for books, courses, articles, frameworks, etc. Thank you!

elements.text: Have you ever dabbled in brand as part of your content role? Do you have any resources to share on how to create a brand story, brand message, tone, etc? I'm looking to learn more about this and would love any recommendations for books, courses, articles, frameworks, etc. Thank you!

text: +1. Besides the Brand Affinity Playbook from Wistia, I don't know much about this.

elements.text: +1. Besides the Brand Affinity Playbook from Wistia, I don't know much about this.

text: We are still figuring this out - went from a humongous testimonial google doc (worked OK for content writing because we can search and pull quotes, but did not work well for sales) to formatted slides with one quote on the slide and additional quotes in the notes for our sales team to use. I think it does depend on how you want to use them, and what those teams would find easiest.

elements.text: We are still figuring this out - went from a humongous testimonial google doc (worked OK for content writing because we can search and pull quotes, but did not work well for sales) to formatted slides with one quote on the slide and additional quotes in the notes for our sales team to use. I think it does depend on how you want to use them, and what those teams would find easiest.

text: I worked on helping start-ups with their branding before my official Content Marketing Manager role, and much of my learning came from meeting other brand managers for coffee! But I also developed my first iteration of brand exercises following Simon Sinek's "The Golden Circle" philosophy. I know some people think his Ted Talks and books are overhyped at this point (which is fair haha), but a lot of his stuff translates to storytelling and brand.

elements.text: I worked on helping start-ups with their branding before my official Content Marketing Manager role, and much of my learning came from meeting other brand managers for coffee! text: For what it's worth, I'm a textbook, total introvert and I (by necessity, until I make the sales hires I'm furiously trying to make right now) do all of our sales.  Script the sales calls and have a deck.  The difference is profound -- it goes from being an undirected mess to a predictable, simple conversation.

text: Any newsletters you think that are unique and worth sharing? Please share them with me as I’m looking for newsletter ideas for a post that I’m working on! TIA.

elements.text: Any newsletters you think that are unique and worth sharing? Please share them with me as I’m looking for newsletter ideas for a post that I’m working on! TIA.

text:
Do you have specific ideas in mind as to what makes a unique newsletter?

Your question brought to mind one of my favorite newsletters right now: Jay Acunzo's Playing Favorites (sent weekly). Topics vary around creativity, content marketing, building brands, etc. and what I really like is that it's digestible, authentic, and I have an Aha! moment while reading almost every edition (i.e. my inbox is full of starred editions). I don't expect these moments, but they just keep coming (which keeps me reading week after week):  <https://www.marketingshowrunners.com/subscribe/>

attachments.title: Subscribe to Playing Favorites - Marketing Showrunners
attachments.fallback: Marketing Showrunners: Subscribe to Playing Favorites - Marketing Showrunners

text: Thanks, <@U015B88C4CA> I follow Jay on Twitter and I can tell from his content there that his newsletter would be great. As for what I mean when I say unique: any newsletter that does something different and ppl can follow that format to launch their own newsletter. For example, Ann Handley writers a personal, letter-like newsletter. Similarly, Databox sends their content, etc.

text: <@U012GHRAHDK> what makes these newsletters different in your view?

elements.text: what makes these newsletters different in your view?

text: I feel like mine, Work Brighter, is unique in the way it covers productivity and work, if submitting your own is allowed :upside_down_face: <https://workbrighter.co/newsletter/>

attachments.title: Work Brighter Weekly
attachments.text: Ready to Work Brighter instead of just smarter?JOIN 2,500+ PRODUCTIVE UNICORNS PERSONALIZING PRODUCTIVITY AND CREATING THEIR OWN RULES FOR WORKProductivity isn't black and white.Nope, that shit is super personal, and it takes more than one tool, app, framework, 'lifehack,' or system to unlock it. So why is so much of the advice about 'working smarter' so one-size-fits-all? Work Brighter is the productivity newsletter that helps you go beyond 'working smarter'......to a version of productivity that makes room for 'unproductive' things like rest, self-care, and fun. What we call working brighter. ​Every Monday morning, you'll receive stories, links, and resources to help

elements.text: I feel like mine, Work Brighter, is unique in the way it covers productivity and work, if submitting your own is allowed

text:
• Divinations is a newsletter with a “3 shorts” series that analyzes 3 news events bullet point by bullet point. <https://divinations.substack.com/|https://divinations.substack.com/>
• Indie Hackers sends out a growth bite newsletter with one actionable idea described in just a paragraph or two <https://www.indiehackers.com/growth-bites|https://www.indiehackers.com/growth-bites>
• The Monday medley is a newsletter that blends curation and opinion, sharing interesting stories and the author’s bullet pointed highlights and takes <https://www.nateliason.com/join|https://www.nateliason.com/join>
• Technically is a newsletter that breaks down technical concepts and uses emoji-laden subsections to break out separate concepts <https://technically.substack.com/|https://technically.substack.com/>
• What’s hot in enterprise tech combines analysis with a big round up of articles and tweets that makes you feel totally up to date on the relevant discourse <https://whatshot.substack.com/|https://whatshot.substack.com/>

attachments.title: Monday Medley Newsletter by Nat Eliason
attachments.text: My once a week roundup of everything interesting I've found or read in the last week, and any new articles or other content I've published.
attachments.fallback: Nat Eliason: Monday Medley Newsletter by Nat Eliason

attachments.title: Technically
attachments.text: Technically explains software and hardware in a simple and engaging way so you can impress your boss.

attachments.title: What's Hot in Enterprise IT/VC
attachments.text: Ed Sim's (@boldstartvc) weekly readings and notes on enterprise VC, software, and scaling startups
